newsitem.title: USA: Airlines drop fall fares for domestic flights.
newsitem.headline: Airlines drop fall fares for domestic flights.

text.p: Some major airlines Wednesday dropped their domestic fares an average of 45 percent in response to price cuts initiated by AMR Corp's American Airlines.
Carriers that followed Tuesday's cuts by American included UAL Corp's United Airlines, Delta Air Lines Inc , and Trans World Airlines Inc.
The rivals said they are matching American's specially priced tickets, which must be bought by September 30 and apply to travel between September 25 and February 13.
United Airlines on Wednesday announced a matching cut, and Trans World Airlines announced discounts of up to 55 percent for 21-day advance purchase domestic flights.
Delta said it was following with similar measures. "We're going to be offering competitive fares. (They) will be in place by the end of the day," said Delta spokesman Bill Berry.
Continental Airlines Inc and USAir Group Inc said they would also be matching American's fares.
American's cuts apply also to its Caribbean flights, which will be 25 percent lower for travel through November 29.
American initiated the cuts on domestic flights late Tuesday, just 10 days after major airlines raised their fares 2.5 percent to match a price increase led by Continental.

"Things are typically somewhat slower in the fall season, and we have good availablity," said American spokesman Tim Smith. "This is what brings in incremental business that might not otherwise be there."
In early afternoon trade, AMR was off 1/2 at 80-1/2.
UAL was off 1/8 at 47-3/8; Continental was up 1/4 at 21- 5/8; TWA was down 1/4 at 10 3/8; and Delta was off 1/4 at 69.
